summary.seg: Alfred the Great's translation of Gregory the Great's Pastoral Care was the first work produced as part of a programme of translation of key works from Latin into Old English. Gregory's Pastoral Care (Regula pastoralis or De cura pastorali) was composed in the 590s, shortly after he became pope, as a handbook for his bishops and other leaders detailing how they should teach and guide their people. It became an enormously influential text, widely disseminated across Christendom.

In producing his translation in the 890s, Alfred added a prefatory letter and a metrical preface in the voice of the book. In the letter addressed to his bishops, Alfred sets out some of his reasons for translating the text. He laments the decline of learning in England and the scarcity of people who could now understand Latin in contrast to earlier times. He sets out the aims of his translation project, to provide English versions of 'those works which are most necessary for all men to know' and to send copies to all his bishops. The translations formed part of a wider programme of educational reform; the bishops are also instructed to educate young men so that they can read the books.

Of the six manuscripts of the vernacular Pastoral Care that survive, two date from Alfred's own time. London, British Library, MS Cotton Tiberius B.xi seems to be the exemplar from which copies were made and distributed but was badly burned in the Cotton Library fire of 1731 and survives as five fragmentary charred leaves - and one unburned leaf now in Kassel which was removed before the Cotton fire. Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Hatton 20 is the copy sent to Bishop Wærferth of Worcester. Cambridge University Library, MS Ii.2.4 was copied in the eleventh century, testifying to enduring interest in the text. It is descended from the copy sent to Wulfsige, Bishop of Sherborne, as the opening line of greeting in the prefatory letter indicates.

The manuscript was acquired by Archbishop Matthew Parker in the 1560s, one of three copies of the text that he owned, the others being Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 12 and Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.5.22.

msItem.author: Gregory I, Pope, approximately 540-604
msItem.title: Alfred the Great's Old English translation of Gregory the Great's Pastoral Care
De cura pastorali, in the translation of Alfred the Great
msItem.note: The text of the translation begins on fol. 10v. It is preceded by a prefatory letter (fols 5r-6v), a metrical preface (fols 6v-7r) and a list of chapter headings (fols 7r-10r)
msItem.rubric: 5r Ðis is seo fore spræc hu sanctus Gregorius þas boc gedihte þe man pastoralem nemnað
msItem.incipit: 5r Ælfred kyning hateð gretan. Ƿulfsige bisceop his ƿordum luflice ˥ freondlice

6v Ðis æryndgeƿrit Agustinus ofer sealtne sæ suðan
brohte
10v Ðu leofesta broður sƿide freondlice ˥ sƿide fremsumlice þu me tældest
msItem.explicit: 146v Ac ic þe bidde þæt þu me on þam scip gebroce þises andƿeardan lifes sum bryd geræce þinra gebeda. þæt ic mæge on syttan oð ic to lande cume
msItem.note: The text ends imperfectly, corresponding to Sweet 1871-72, p. 467, line 25.
msItem.filiation:
The preface indicates that this copy derives from the one sent by Alfred to Wulfsige who was bishop of Sherborne in the 890s. Other versions of the text are found in:
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 12
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.5.22
London, British Library, MS Cotton Otho B. ii
London, British Library, MS Cotton Otho B. x
London, British Library, MS Cotton Tiberius B. xi + Kassel, Landesbibliothek, Anhang 19
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Junius 53 (a transcript made by Franciscus Junius (1589-1677) Junius, Franciscus, 1589-1677 in the seventeenth century, based on Tiberius B. xi.)

support.p: Fols 3-4, 150-51 are post-medieval parchment. Fols 5-146 are medieval parchment, arranged HHFF. Fol. 149 is a medieval parchment flyleaf; fol. 149bis is a modern paper leaf to which documents have been pasted; fols 2bis and 151bis are modern parchment leaves.

supportDesc.extent:
1 (pastedown), 2bis, 3-146, 149, 149bis, 150, 150bis, 151, 151bis, 152 (pastedown). Two leaves are missing at the beginning before fol. 3 and two at the end after fol. 146. 330 225
278 160

foliation.p: Modern pencil foliation in the top right-hand corner of each recto 3-146, 149-151.
16th-century Parkerian pagination 1-287 in red crayon in the top right-hand corner of each recto from fol. 3-149. This has been struck through in pencil.

collation.p:
The manuscript consists of 18 quires as follows:
One 16th-century parchment leaf pasted to the inside front cover (fol. 1)
One modern parchment flyleaf (fol. 2bis)
Two 16th-century parchment leaves (fols 3-4)
Quire a-r8 (fols 5-140); leaves 2 and 7 in quire c (fols 22 and 27) are half-sheets
Quire s8 (fols 141-46), wanting leaves 7 and 8
One medieval parchment flyleaf (fol. 149)
One modern paper leaf. Two letters from John Jewel to Matthew Parker, previously pasted on fol. 149v, are pasted to the recto (fol. 149bis)
One 16th-century parchment leaf with part of a document on the verso. It was originally pasted to fol. 151 since 151r shows the offset (fol. 150)
One 16th-century parchment stub (fol. 150bis)
One 16th-century flyleaf (fol. 151)
One modern parchment flyleaf (fol. 151bis)
One 16th-century parchment leaf pasted to the inside back cover (fol. 152)
collation.signatures: Signatures (a-s) added in pencil by Henry Bradshaw (1831-1886) Bradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886 in the bottom right-hand corner of the first recto of each quire. Bradshaw also marked the recto of the fifth leaf of most quires with a '+'.

condition.p: Fols 1, 3-4, 149, 150-52 show evidence of damage caused by the four metal bosses that were once attached to the upper and lower covers.

Fols 5-28 show evidence of tears and missing portions now repaired with modern paper; fol. 13 was particularly badly damaged with losses to the upper and right-hand margins resulting in some loss of text.
There are small holes in some leaves which the scribe has written around, e.g. fol. 130.

layout.p: Written in a single column of 24 lines. Drypoint ruled with double bounding lines on both sides of the frame, ca. 10 mm apart. Pricking in the outer margins only, mostly trimmed but still visible e.g. on fol. 82r.

handNote.p: Written in English vernacular minuscule by a single scribe throughout. The script is round and upright, sharing many of the principal characteristics of the Exeter type. Drage calls it the most calligraphically accomplished piece of insular minuscule produced at Exeter (Drage 1975:173). When Latin is used, the letter forms are distinctly different. '

decoDesc.decoNote: Titles are in metallic red in the script and hand of the text.

Coloured initials at the start of each chapter, two or three lines in height, are alternately red, blue and green. They usually have guide-letters, and half of the initial is usually indented to the left.

list.item: Ker notes some faintly pencilled Latin glosses, e.g. on f. 30, which appear to be of s. xiii (Ker 1957:28). See the top of the page. See also, for example, fol. 92r, line 23.

Latin translations of Alfred's prefatory letter and the metrical preface are copied on fols 3v-4v in a 16th-century hand. A hand of similar date has added an interlinear modern English gloss to those two texts on fols 5r-7r Graham suggests that this gloss probably served as a model for the gloss accompanying the edition of the prose and metrical prefaces included in Matthew Parker's 1574 edition of Asser's life of King Alfred, Ælfredi regis res gestae (Graham 1995:633-34).

Graham notes the name 'Johannes Parker' in red crayon in the top right-hand corner of fol. 5r, probably in Matthew Parker's hand (Graham 1995:636-37). He suggests that the archbishop wrote the names of his two sons in several of his volumes, probably indicating which of them should inherit it. One of his other copies of the Pastoral Care (Trinity R.5.22) is inscribed 'Matthaeus Parker'.
Other 16th-century additions include the underlining of two lines in red crayon on fol. 146v and the addition of the word finis at the foot of the same page.

The text on the 16th-century flyleaf, fol. 150v, and readable from the offset on fol. 151r, is a document in Latin from Richard Lyell, Doctor of Law and vicar-general to Thomas Thirlby, Bishop of Westminster concerning a matrimonial case. The document contains a date in 1543, probably the year in which it was issued. For more details see Graham 1995:632.
An inscription in an early modern hand on the front pastedown

Abraham Wheelocke (1593-1653) Wheelocke, Abraham, 1593-1653 notes in the upper margin of the front pastedown that he began to read the text on 3 September 1638 and finished it on 17 July 1639. There are additional notes in his hand on fol. 150r, formerly the back pastedown.
References to chapter numbers in the Latin text are added throughout in an early modern hand.
Shelfmarks are added on the front pastedown (253, D.β.3 and Ii-2-4) and on fol. 150r (4:2.3).
Interlinear Latin glosses in pencil are added intermittently throughout in a hand (or hands) that are probably modern.

In addition to adding foliation and signatures to the MS, Henry Bradshaw added notifications of missing leaves on the front pastedown and fol. 146v, and a summary of the collation on the back pastedown in the 19th century.
In the course of repairs to the manuscript in 1967, two modern parchment leaves were added, fols 2bis and 151bis.

bindingDesc.p: Sixteenth-century binding of dark brown leather over wooden boards, rebacked by Douglas Cockerell & Son, Grantchester, May 1967. Both covers have a blind-tooled frame and central ornament. The four bosses from each cover are now missing but traces of them remain. The brass fittings of two clasps and one strap remain and there are metal fittings to the top and bottom corners of both covers. On the spine in gold letters: Gregorii regula pastoralis and the classmark.
Monochrome photographs taken by Douglas Cockerell when the pastedowns were lifted in the course of repairs show evidence that the boards had been used in a previous binding.

The lower cover shows traces of the presence of the book label which was pasted to fol. 3r when Ker saw the MS in the 1950s but which is now pasted to the front pastedown. The label reads: Pastoral: Gregorii ex Versione Aluredi regis saxon' in a 16th-century hand.
On the fore-edge of the book is written Gregori Pastorale, Alfred R Saxon in black ink.

accMat.p: Two letters from John Jewel (1522-1571) Jewel, John, 1522-1571 , Bishop of Salisbury, to Matthew Parker, Archbishop of Canterbury, dated January 1568, were pasted on to fol. 149v when Ker examined this manuscript and are now pasted to a modern paper leaf (fol. 150bis). They refer to an Old English manuscript sent to Parker from Salisbury, almost certainly Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.5.22, which also contains a copy of Alfred's translation of the Pastoral Care.

The box in which the manuscript is kept also contains a photocopy of monochrome photographs by Douglas Cockerell of the interior of the boards taken when the pastedowns were lifted in the course of repairs.

origin.origDate: Third quarter of the 11th century C.E.

history.provenance: Almost certainly written at Exeter. It was acquired by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575 , Archbishop of Canterbury probably before 1568 and presumably directly from the chapter library at Exeter. Parker owned several Exeter manuscripts, for example, CUL MS Ii.2.11 which contains an inscription recording its donation to Parker by Gregory Dodds, Dean of Exeter, by 1566. MS Ii.2.4 is no. 6 in the listing of manuscripts given to Cambridge University Library by Parker in 1574.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry is based with permission on the description produced for The Production and Use of English Manuscripts 1060-1220 by Takako Kato with the assistance of Owen Roberson and Hollie Morgan.
